Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Reticulation and chromosomal evolution in Amaryllidaceae tribe Hippeastreae
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project seeks to examine reticulate evolution in a chromosomally diverse group of Neotropical flowering plants, the Amaryllidaceae (amaryllis family). The generic classification of Amaryllidaceae tribe Hippeastreae, which includes 10-12 genera and ~180 species, including amaryllis, rain lilies, and other ornamentals, remains controversial, despite the horticultural importance of these plants. This group of monocots is putatively descended from an ancient hybridization event, and additional, more recent hybridizations have confounded evolutionary relationships. The main goals are to: 1) assess the extent and nature of reticulate evolution in Hippeastreae; and 2) explore patterns of chromosome evolution in a phylogenetic context. The underlying evolutionary history, or phylogeny, of the group will be investigated with DNA sequences of multiple nuclear genes obtained by next-generation sequencing techniques. Reticulate evolution will be addressed through methods that consider gene tree heterogeneity and network representations of the phylogeny. Chromosomal evolution will be assessed through modeling of chromosome number variation and mapping of cytological characters, including genetic, structural, and numerical differences, onto evolutionary trees. This project will provide general insights into reticulation in plant evolution at different temporal scales and ploidy levels (genome duplication) through an integrative molecular approach.

This research will provide the co-PI with significant training opportunities in diverse molecular and cytogenetic techniques, which he will apply as a teacher and researcher in his home country, Chile. Hence, he will contribute to the development of systematics research programs in Chile, where this field currently lacks sufficient expertise. This project will result in a revised classification of Hippeastreae, which will benefit other scientists and horticulturists working with these plants. This classification will be integrated into eMonocot, a global online resource for monocot taxonomy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The current fast pace of extinctions urges a better understanding of biodiversity in our changing world. This task does not only involve the inventorying of all life on Earth but also the notion of how this diversity of organisms came to be and the genealogical relationships between them. We are interested in a group of Neotropical lilies that include plants known as rain-, zephyr-, Aztec-, or Amaryllis-lilies, formally called Amaryllidaceae tribe Hippeastreae. Members of this group have been cultivated for centuries due to the beauty of their flowers. On the other hand, their taxonomy (how they are named and classified), has historically sparked controversy between specialists and confusion by the general public and amateur plant-growers. Previous attempts to understand the evolutionary history (phylogeny) of Hippeastreae proved elusive to infer due to the potential effect of ancient hybridization events.

The research supported by this award was designed to study the phylogeny and chromosomes of Hippeastreae. The results of our experiments gave us a number of new insights into Hippeastreae relationships and evolution. In particular, we confirmed that hybridizations have been frequent and important in the history of these plants, and therefore, that the phylogeny is more appropriately represented as an interbranching network rather than as a strictly tree-like branching pattern. A methodological contribution of this research was the MarkerMiner software, which is designed to facilitate the identification of genes that can be used to elucidate the evolutionary relationships between plant species. Furthermore, the results of this research served as a basis to develop a new classification for Hippeastreae that will ultimately enhance the communication among those studying Amaryllidaceae and between specialists and other scientists, horticulturalists, or plant-lovers.

This award constituted significant support for the development and improvement of a PhD dissertation by a Chilean botanist. The research provided this graduate student with significant training opportunities in molecular techniques and modern cytological approaches that he will apply as a teacher and researcher upon his return to his home country. In this way, this award will contribute to the development of systematics research in Chile, where this field currently lacks extensive expertise. Besides the manuscript describing the MarkerMiner software, this research will produce approximately four additional publications, which are currently in preparation. The Hippeastreae classification generated in this research will be adopted by the Flora of Brazil Online 2020 project, and we expect it to be supported in the future by other floristic and taxonomic projects throughout the geographic regions where these plants are distributed.
